Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Gravity Meter for Geophysical research and teaching
Award.AbstractNarration:
1531745
Mickus

Funding from this Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program grant will support acquisition of a relative gravimeter to support research and research training in geology and geophysics at Missouri State University, a non-Ph.D. granting institution. The gravimeter would complement other geophysical imaging equipment (e.g. resistivity) at Missouri State and support experiential learning in techniques in exploration geophysics for studies of regional interest thereby fostering their future employability in fields that routinely engage in water, hydrocarbon and mineral deposit studies, an aspect of the proposal that is congruent with NSFs mission of promoting the national welfare.

The investigator will employ the relative gravimeter for studies that attempt to define the subsurface location of magmas in both hot spot volcanic settings and on continental volcanoes, definition of the geometry and location rare earth ore deposits in Missouri, and location and study of the subsurface karst features and basinal structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF award 1531745 was awarded to Dr. Kevin Mickus in order to purchase a gravity meter in order to study geological problems. The gravity meter, Burris, was obtained in 2016 and has been used in several research and student projects. Plus it has been used in Geology senior/graduate courses that taught geophysical methods. Several of these students are now pursuing advance degrees that involve the gravity method. A gravity is an useful tool in delineating subsurface density variations that can be related to tectonic, petroleum, mineral resource, environmental and engineering studies. Basically any subsurface density variation that can be related to a geologic process.

The NSF purchased gravity meter has been used in several studies including determining the subsurface structure of the Bhutanese Himalayas, thickness of the sediments of the Methow Basin in Washington State, locating cavern systems in southwest Missouri, locating iron oxide deposits related to REE mineralization in southeast Missouri and locating regions of hydrothermal alteration in the geyser basin of western Yellowstone National Park. The Bhutan study involved the Bhutanese Geological Survey and a MS student from Bhutan who studied at Missouri State University. The student and I over a three year period collected over 3000 data points that after processing have shown that the thickness of the Bhutan crust varies both North to South, and more surprisingly East to West. The east to west variations have implications on the earthquake potential in eastern Bhutan. The geophysical study in southwest Missouri involved electrical resistivity, VLF-electromagnetics and gravity to investigate the extent of a suspected cavern and sinkhole system that is adjacent to a new housing development. The electrical resistivity and gravity study indicated that there is an extensive cavern system approximately 5 meter below the surface which could be susceptable to forming sinkholes. This study was done by both senior undergraduate students and a graduate student for her MS thesis. All three students currently working for environmental or state government agencies where a knowledge of geophysical methods in determine the subsuface structures in critical in providing remediation of job sites.
